comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Lovely shot of the cavalry getting ready.  Interesting barrack buildings in the background, all much the same as those in such places as Birr, Templemore etc. except that the space above the archway is not built up and the clock is not mounted on the tower of the cupola.

comment.author: 59842170@N00
comment._content: Thats a great picture - some equipment each cavalry trooper had. Hope the clock was working!!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/rockface] Well, like Rupert Brooke's poem, The Old Vicarage, Grantchester where the question is asked: "Stands the Church clock at ten to three?" - in this photo, it'll always be a case of "Stands the Barracks clock at eleven twenty?"...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 54059458@N02
comment._content: Can you spot the officers - they seem to have different tunics. Spotted this image of todays cavalry!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/54059458@N02] A lot more "horse power" in your photo, methinks!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: Newbridge Barracks Ordnance Ground was there before the railway was built. maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,680504,715008,6,7 Really handy, these old maps.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] Thank you. You and [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] are sterling and determined map searchers!  :)
